qas.question: When was the earliest church labeled "Baptist" traced to?
Where was the earliest church labeled "Baptist" traced to?
Who was the pastor of the earliest church labeled "Baptist"?
Who believed Christ's atonement only extended to the elect?
When did Roger Williams established the first Baptist congregation in the North American colonies?
When was the earliest church labeled "Christian" traced to?
Where was the earliest church labeled "Christian" traced to?
Who was the pastor of the earliest church labeled "Christian"?
Who believed Christ's atonement extended to all of life?
When did Roger Williams establish the first Baptist congregation in South America?

context: Historians trace the earliest church labeled "Baptist" back to <a0_0><b5_0>1609<b5_0/><a0_0/> in <a1_0><b6_0>Amsterdam<b6_0/><a1_0/>, with English Separatist <a2_0><b7_0>John Smyth<b7_0/><a2_0/> as its pastor. In accordance with his reading of the New Testament, he rejected baptism of infants and instituted baptism only of believing adults. Baptist practice spread to England, where the General Baptists considered Christ's atonement to extend to all people, while the <a3_0><b8_0>Particular Baptists<b8_0/><a3_0/> believed that it extended only to the elect. In <a4_0><b9_0>1638<b9_0/><a4_0/>, Roger Williams established the first Baptist congregation in the North American colonies. In the mid-18th century, the First Great Awakening increased Baptist growth in both New England and the South. The Second Great Awakening in the South in the early 19th century increased church membership, as did the preachers' lessening of support for abolition and manumission of slavery, which had been part of the 18th-century teachings. Baptist missionaries have spread their church to every continent.
